title: Understanding Risk and Safety
subject: Health and Physical Education

contentSections.title: Spotting Hazards
contentSections.content: A hazard is something that could hurt you. Hazards can be found in many places - at home, at school, and when we are out. Some hazards are easy to see, like a wet floor that is slippery or a broken toy with sharp edges. Other hazards are harder to spot. Learning to look for hazards helps us stay safe. When you see a hazard, you should tell an adult so they can fix it or help you stay safe.

contentSections.title: Safe and Unsafe Choices
contentSections.content: Every day we make choices. Some choices are safe, and some are unsafe. A safe choice protects us from getting hurt. An unsafe choice could lead to an accident or injury. For example, wearing a seatbelt is a safe choice. Running near a swimming pool is an unsafe choice because you could slip and fall. Before you do something, you can ask yourself: 'Could this hurt me or someone else?' If the answer is yes, it's probably unsafe.

contentSections.title: Warning Signs
contentSections.content: Warning signs help keep us safe by telling us about dangers. Some warning signs use pictures, like a picture of flames to show fire danger. Some use colours - red often means stop or danger. Signs might have words like 'STOP', 'DANGER', or 'KEEP OUT'. When you see a warning sign, you should pay attention to it. The sign is there to protect you from something that could hurt you.

contentSections.title: Getting Help
contentSections.content: When something feels unsafe, it's important to get help from a trusted adult. Trusted adults include parents, carers, teachers, and other grown-ups who look after you. You can ask for help when you see a hazard, when you're not sure if something is safe, or when you feel worried about a situation. It's never wrong to ask for help. Keeping yourself safe is more important than doing something by yourself.

unistructural.stem: Name one thing that is a hazard.

multistructural.stem: List three trusted adults you could go to for help if something was unsafe.

relational.stem: Explain why telling an adult about a hazard helps keep everyone safe.
relational.modelResponse: Telling an adult about a hazard helps keep everyone safe because adults can fix the problem or warn others. For example, if I tell a teacher about water on the floor, they can clean it up or put a sign near it. This stops other people from slipping and getting hurt. If I didn't tell anyone, someone might not see the hazard and have an accident.
relational.rubric: Explains the connection between reporting hazards and preventing harm. Shows understanding that adults can act to fix problems or warn others. May give an example.

extendedAbstract.stem: Think about why some people take unsafe risks even when they know it's dangerous. What do you think?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Some people take unsafe risks even when they know it's dangerous for different reasons. They might want to look brave in front of friends and not want to seem scared. They might think bad things only happen to other people, not to them. They might be in a hurry and think it will be faster to do the unsafe thing. Sometimes people don't really understand how bad the consequences could be. Understanding why people take risks can help us make better choices ourselves.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies multiple reasons people might take risks despite knowing danger. Shows abstract thinking about human behaviour. May connect to how understanding this could help with safety choices.

contentSections.title: Risks in Different Environments
contentSections.content: Different places have different risks. At home, risks might include hot appliances, electrical outlets, and stairs. At school, risks might include science equipment, playground equipment, and sports activities. Outdoors, risks could include traffic, weather, and natural hazards. By thinking about the specific risks in each environment, you can be better prepared to stay safe. The key is to be aware of your surroundings and adjust your behaviour based on where you are.

contentSections.title: What Makes Risks Serious
contentSections.content: Not all risks are the same. Two things help us understand how serious a risk is: likelihood (how likely it is to happen) and severity (how bad the harm could be). A risk that is very likely to happen AND would cause serious harm is a high-level risk that needs immediate action. A risk that is unlikely to happen and would only cause minor harm is a lower-level risk. Understanding this helps us know which risks need the most attention.

contentSections.title: Taking Precautions
contentSections.content: A precaution is something you do to prevent harm. Wearing a helmet when cycling is a precaution. Looking both ways before crossing the road is a precaution. Following safety rules in science class is a precaution. Good precautions match the risk - more serious risks need more careful precautions. Taking precautions doesn't mean you're scared; it means you're being smart about protecting yourself.

contentSections.title: Making Safer Choices
contentSections.content: When you need to make a choice, you can ask yourself some questions to help you stay safe. What could go wrong? How bad could it be? What can I do to reduce the risk? Is there a safer way to do this? If you're unsure, it's okay to wait, ask for help, or choose a different option. Making safer choices is a skill that gets better with practice.

multistructural.stem: List four different precautions you could take when riding a bike.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four precautions when riding a bike are: 1) Wearing a helmet, 2) Checking brakes work before riding, 3) Using lights and reflectors when it's dark, 4) Obeying road rules and signals.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant bike safety precautions. May include helmet, lights, brakes, following rules, appropriate clothing, staying alert, using hand signals, or similar.

relational.stem: Explain how likelihood and severity work together to determine how serious a risk is.
relational.modelResponse: Likelihood and severity work together to determine risk level. Likelihood is how probable the harm is to happen, and severity is how bad the harm could be. A risk that is very likely AND very severe is the most serious - like walking on thin ice over deep water. A risk that is unlikely AND not very severe is least serious - like a small paper cut from handling a book. Some risks might be likely but not severe (like getting a blister from new shoes) or unlikely but severe (like being struck by lightning). Understanding both factors helps us decide which risks need the most attention and precaution.
relational.rubric: Explains how both factors contribute to overall risk level. Shows understanding that high likelihood + high severity = most serious risk. May give examples to illustrate different combinations.

extendedAbstract.stem: Think about how the risks in your life will change as you get older and more independent. What new risks will you face and what skills will you need?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: As I get older and more independent, I'll face new risks. When I can drive, I'll face road risks and need skills in safe driving and decision-making about driving conditions. Living more independently means risks with cooking, managing money, and taking care of my health - needing skills in these areas. Social risks change too - making decisions about relationships, parties, and peer pressure. Online risks increase as I have more digital independence. I'll need skills in critical thinking, planning ahead, knowing when to ask for help, and assessing risks in new situations. The common thread is that I'll need to make more decisions for myself, so developing good judgement and decision-making skills is essential.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies multiple new risks that come with increased age and independence. Connects these to skills needed. Shows ability to think abstractly about future development and changing circumstances.

contentSections.title: Risk Assessment Framework
contentSections.content: Risk assessment is a systematic process for evaluating safety. First, identify the hazards - what could cause harm? Second, assess the risk - how likely is harm to occur, and how severe could it be? Third, implement control measures - what can be done to reduce the risk? Fourth, monitor and review - did the controls work? This framework can be applied to activities from sports and recreation to science experiments and everyday decisions. Formal risk assessments are used in workplaces, schools, and event planning.

contentSections.title: Harm Minimisation Principles
contentSections.content: Harm minimisation is a realistic approach that acknowledges risk cannot always be eliminated, so the focus is on reducing harm. Key principles include: accepting that some risk-taking is normal; providing accurate information rather than only scare tactics; focusing on practical strategies that reduce harm; and recognising that people make choices, so we should help them make safer ones. Harm minimisation doesn't mean encouraging risky behaviour - it means being practical about reducing negative outcomes when risks are taken.

contentSections.title: Hierarchy of Controls
contentSections.content: The hierarchy of controls ranks strategies from most to least effective. Elimination removes the hazard completely - most effective but not always possible. Substitution replaces the hazard with something safer. Engineering controls physically reduce exposure to the hazard. Administrative controls change how people work or behave. Personal protective equipment (PPE) is the last line of defence. Effective risk management often combines multiple levels of control. Higher-level controls are preferred because they don't rely on human behaviour.

contentSections.title: Making Safe Decisions
contentSections.content: Safe decision-making involves several considerations. First, gather information about the situation and potential risks. Second, consider the consequences - both benefits and potential harms. Third, identify ways to reduce risk while still achieving your goal. Fourth, have a contingency plan if something goes wrong. Fifth, be willing to change your mind if conditions change or risks are higher than expected. Good decision-making also involves recognising when peer pressure or emotions might be affecting your judgement.

remember.question: What are the four steps in the risk assessment framework?

options.text: Plan, Do, Check, Act
options.feedback: This is a different framework. The risk assessment framework focuses on hazards, risk, controls, and review.

options.text: Identify hazards, assess risk, implement controls, monitor and review
options.feedback: Correct! These four steps guide systematic risk assessment.

options.text: Stop, Look, Listen, Think
options.feedback: This is a simpler safety approach, not the full risk assessment framework.

options.text: Identify, Ignore, Accept, Forget
options.feedback: This is not correct - risks should be addressed, not ignored or forgotten.

understand.question: Why is elimination considered the most effective control measure in the hierarchy of controls?

options.text: Because it is the cheapest option
options.feedback: Cost isn't the reason - elimination is most effective because of how completely it addresses the hazard.

options.text: Because completely removing the hazard means the risk no longer exists
options.feedback: Correct! When the hazard is eliminated entirely, there's no possibility of that specific harm occurring.

options.text: Because it doesn't require any training
options.feedback: Training requirements aren't why elimination is ranked highest.

options.text: Because people always prefer elimination
options.feedback: People's preferences don't determine the hierarchy - effectiveness does.

apply.question: Your school is planning an outdoor camp with hiking activities. Apply the risk assessment framework by identifying one hazard and suggesting control measures from different levels of the hierarchy.

options.text: Cancel the camp entirely since hiking is risky
options.feedback: This eliminates the activity but doesn't demonstrate applying the framework thoughtfully.

options.text: Hazard: Uneven terrain causing falls. Controls: Choose trails with better surfaces (substitution), provide walking poles (engineering), train students on safe hiking (administrative), require sturdy footwear (PPE)
options.feedback: Correct! This identifies a specific hazard and applies multiple levels of control appropriately.

options.text: Just tell students to be careful
options.feedback: This is only one administrative control and doesn't use the full framework.

options.text: Only do the easy walks to avoid any risk
options.feedback: This shows substitution but doesn't demonstrate the full framework application.

analyse.question: Analyse why harm minimisation focuses on reducing negative outcomes rather than simply telling people not to take risks.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse the practical limitations of abstinence-only approaches. Key points: some risk-taking is normal and inevitable, especially for adolescents; people who choose to take risks need strategies to reduce harm; scare tactics alone aren't effective in changing behaviour; providing accurate information empowers better decisions; reducing harm is more achievable than eliminating all risk. Strong responses recognise the balance between idealism and practical reality.
successCriteria: Explains why risk-taking cannot be completely prevented
Analyses the limitations of telling people simply not to take risks
Discusses how harm minimisation provides practical strategies
Shows understanding of the realistic approach to safety

evaluate.question: Evaluate the following risk management plan for a school sports carnival: 'We will have first aid staff on site and tell students to stay hydrated.' Is this adequate? What would you add or change?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should evaluate this plan as incomplete. While it includes some controls (first aid, hydration advice), it lacks systematic risk assessment and multiple control levels. Additions might include: identifying specific hazards (heat, injuries, equipment), providing shade (engineering control), scheduling intense activities for cooler times (administrative), training supervisors in emergency response, having a weather contingency plan, ensuring appropriate equipment and facilities.
successCriteria: Evaluates the current plan as inadequate
Identifies what is missing from the plan
Suggests specific additions using hierarchy of controls
Demonstrates understanding of comprehensive risk management

create.question: Create a complete risk assessment for an activity you enjoy (could be sport, cooking, crafting, or similar). Include hazard identification, risk rating, and control measures at multiple levels.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students create a comprehensive risk assessment for their chosen activity. Should include: the activity identified, at least 3 hazards specific to that activity, assessment of likelihood and severity for each, control measures at different hierarchy levels, and consideration of how to monitor effectiveness. Assessment should be realistic and demonstrate genuine understanding of the activity's risks.
successCriteria: Identifies activity and at least 3 relevant hazards
Assesses likelihood and severity for each hazard
Proposes control measures at multiple hierarchy levels
Shows practical understanding of the activity and its risks

unistructural.modelResponse: Harm minimisation means reducing the negative consequences of risky situations or behaviours.
unistructural.rubric: Correctly defines harm minimisation as reducing negative outcomes or consequences of risk.

multistructural.stem: List the five levels of the hierarchy of controls from most to least effective.
multistructural.modelResponse: The five levels of the hierarchy of controls from most to least effective are: 1) Elimination - removing the hazard, 2) Substitution - replacing with something safer, 3) Engineering controls - physical changes, 4) Administrative controls - changing procedures, 5) Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).
multistructural.rubric: Correctly lists all five levels in order from most to least effective.

relational.stem: Explain how the four steps of risk assessment work together to create a safer outcome.
relational.modelResponse: The four steps of risk assessment work together systematically. First, identifying hazards ensures you know what could cause harm - without this, you might miss important risks. Second, assessing the risk helps you prioritise - focusing resources on the most likely and severe risks. Third, implementing controls addresses the risks you've identified and assessed - matching control measures to the level of risk. Fourth, monitoring and reviewing completes the cycle - checking if controls are working and adjusting if needed. Each step builds on the previous one, and the review step connects back to identification, creating an ongoing improvement process. Without all steps working together, risks could be missed, under-controlled, or left unchanged even when controls fail.
relational.rubric: Explains how each step connects to the others. Shows understanding that the process is systematic and cyclical. Identifies what would be missed without each step working together.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how risk perception can differ between adolescents and adults. How might this affect safety strategies targeted at young people?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Risk perception differs between adolescents and adults due to brain development, experience, and social factors. Adolescent brains are still developing in areas controlling impulse and long-term thinking, which can lead to underestimating risks or overweighting immediate rewards. Adolescents have less experience with consequences, so risks may seem more abstract. Peer influence is stronger, potentially affecting risk-taking. Adults may overestimate some risks based on media or anxiety. These differences have implications for safety strategies: for young people, abstract warnings may be less effective than concrete, relatable examples. Harm minimisation approaches that acknowledge risk-taking may be more effective than abstinence-only messages. Peer-led education can leverage social influence positively. Strategies that engage the reward-seeking tendency (making safe behaviour rewarding) may work better than fear-based approaches. Understanding these differences helps create more effective, developmentally appropriate safety education.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies multiple factors affecting risk perception differences. Connects these to implications for safety strategies. Shows sophisticated understanding of adolescent development and its relevance to health education. Proposes strategies that account for these differences.

contentSections.title: Understanding Risk Perception
contentSections.content: Risk perception is subjective and influenced by many factors. Cognitive biases affect judgement: optimism bias makes us think 'it won't happen to me'; availability bias leads us to overestimate risks we've heard about recently; affect bias means emotions influence risk assessment. Personal experience, cultural background, and trust in information sources also shape perception. Understanding these influences helps explain why people sometimes underestimate serious risks or overestimate unlikely ones. Effective safety communication must account for how people actually perceive risk, not just objective risk levels.

contentSections.title: Social and Contextual Factors
contentSections.content: Risk and safety are shaped by social and contextual factors beyond individual choice. Socioeconomic status affects exposure to hazards and access to safety resources. Cultural norms influence acceptable risk levels and safety behaviours. Peer influence is particularly strong during adolescence. Environmental conditions like housing quality, neighbourhood safety, and workplace conditions create differential risk exposure. These social determinants mean that safety interventions focused only on individual behaviour miss important factors. Addressing risk requires understanding the broader context in which decisions are made.

contentSections.title: Evaluating Risk Communication
contentSections.content: Risk communication aims to help people understand and respond to risks. Effective communication is clear, accurate, and action-oriented. It acknowledges uncertainty rather than oversimplifying. Common problems include: using statistics that are hard to understand; fear-based messaging that can backfire; ignoring audience values and concerns; and failing to provide actionable steps. Good risk communication considers the audience, uses relatable comparisons, addresses emotional responses, and empowers action. Critically evaluating risk messages helps us identify effective communication and recognise manipulation.

contentSections.title: Advocacy for Safer Communities
contentSections.content: Young people can advocate for safety improvements in their communities. This might involve identifying safety issues in schools or neighbourhoods; gathering evidence through observation, surveys, or research; proposing solutions based on evidence and community input; communicating with decision-makers; and mobilising peer support. Effective advocacy requires understanding both the technical aspects of safety and how change happens in organisations and communities. Youth perspectives are valuable because young people often notice issues that adults overlook.

remember.question: What is optimism bias in relation to risk perception?

options.text: The tendency to see positive outcomes in all situations
options.feedback: Optimism bias specifically relates to comparative risk judgement, not general optimism.

options.text: The tendency to believe negative events are less likely to happen to oneself than to others
options.feedback: Correct! Optimism bias leads people to think 'it won't happen to me' even when statistical risk is similar to others.

options.text: The ability to see risks clearly and act on them
options.feedback: This would be accurate risk perception, not optimism bias which is a form of inaccuracy.

options.text: The preference for taking more risks
options.feedback: Risk preference is different from optimism bias about likelihood.

understand.question: Why do social determinants matter for understanding risk and safety?

options.text: Because some people choose to live in unsafe conditions
options.feedback: This frames it as individual choice, missing the systemic nature of social determinants.

options.text: Because conditions like socioeconomic status, housing, and environment affect exposure to hazards and access to safety resources
options.feedback: Correct! Social determinants shape risk exposure and capacity to respond, beyond individual choices.

options.text: Because they make risk assessment too complicated
options.feedback: Understanding social determinants improves risk assessment, not complicates it.

options.text: Because society makes all decisions about safety
options.feedback: Both individuals and social factors play roles in safety.

apply.question: You're designing a safety campaign to reduce texting while walking among students. Applying understanding of risk perception, which approach is most likely to be effective?

options.text: Show statistics about pedestrian injuries nationally
options.feedback: Abstract statistics often don't overcome optimism bias - people think 'that won't be me'.

options.text: Tell students texting while walking is banned and they'll get detention
options.feedback: Punishment threats may not address the underlying behaviour and can create resistance.

options.text: Use relatable scenarios with student stories, acknowledge people will still text, and provide practical strategies for safer habits
options.feedback: Correct! This addresses optimism bias through relatability, acknowledges reality, and provides actionable alternatives.

options.text: Ignore the issue because students won't change their behaviour anyway
options.feedback: Well-designed interventions can change behaviour, especially when they understand their audience.

analyse.question: Analyse why fear-based safety campaigns sometimes have the opposite of their intended effect.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple psychological mechanisms. Key points: extreme fear can cause avoidance of the message rather than the behaviour; people may dismiss messages as exaggerated; fear without actionable solutions creates helplessness; optimism bias may cause people to think it applies to others not themselves; repeated fear messages can cause desensitisation; fear can be associated with shame, reducing help-seeking. Strong responses connect psychological factors to campaign design implications.
successCriteria: Identifies multiple reasons fear-based campaigns can backfire
Explains psychological mechanisms involved
Connects analysis to implications for effective communication
Demonstrates sophisticated understanding of behaviour change

evaluate.question: Evaluate whether schools should use the precautionary principle when making safety decisions, or whether they should wait for conclusive evidence of harm. Consider examples to support your evaluation.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should present a nuanced evaluation. Arguments for precautionary principle: protects students from potential serious harm, schools have duty of care, some harms are irreversible, waiting for conclusive evidence means accepting harm in the meantime. Arguments against strict application: could lead to excessive restriction, cost implications, may not be evidence-based. Strong responses find a balanced position, perhaps suggesting precaution for potentially serious/irreversible harms while seeking evidence for less serious concerns.
successCriteria: Presents arguments for applying precautionary principle
Considers limitations or challenges with this approach
Uses examples to support evaluation
Reaches a reasoned conclusion that acknowledges complexity

create.question: Create an advocacy proposal for a safety improvement in your school or community. Include the safety issue, evidence supporting the need for change, proposed solutions, and a strategy for gaining support.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students create a comprehensive advocacy proposal. Should include: clearly identified safety issue with specific concerns, evidence gathered or cited supporting the need, solutions that are practical and address root causes, strategy for building support and communicating with decision-makers. Proposal should demonstrate understanding of how to create change in institutions and communities.
successCriteria: Identifies a specific, genuine safety issue
Provides evidence supporting the need for change
Proposes practical and effective solutions
Includes realistic strategy for advocacy and implementation

unistructural.stem: Name one cognitive bias that affects risk perception.
unistructural.rubric: Names one relevant cognitive bias such as optimism bias, availability bias, or affect bias.

multistructural.stem: List four social determinants that can affect safety outcomes.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four social determinants that affect safety outcomes are: 1) Socioeconomic status affecting access to safety resources, 2) Housing quality and neighbourhood conditions, 3) Cultural norms around safety behaviours, 4) Access to education and information about risks.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant social determinants. May include socioeconomic status, housing, neighbourhood, culture, education, employment conditions, or access to services.

relational.stem: Explain how cognitive biases and social factors can interact to affect risk-taking behaviour in adolescents.
relational.modelResponse: Cognitive biases and social factors interact in complex ways for adolescents. Optimism bias ('it won't happen to me') combines with peer influence - if friends are taking risks, the behaviour seems even safer because people they know do it without harm. Availability bias is shaped by social media, where exciting risk-taking is often shared but negative consequences are less visible. Social determinants like socioeconomic status can affect exposure to both risks and safety education, while cultural norms may either reinforce or challenge risk-taking. The developing adolescent brain's sensitivity to peer influence amplifies social effects. This means that understanding adolescent risk behaviour requires considering both individual psychology and social context - neither alone explains the full picture.
relational.rubric: Explains how cognitive biases and social factors interact rather than operate independently. Shows understanding of adolescent-specific factors. Demonstrates sophisticated analysis of multiple influences on behaviour.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how systemic factors might make some communities experience higher safety risks than others. What would truly equitable safety look like, and what changes would be needed to achieve it?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Systemic factors create unequal safety outcomes across communities. Lower socioeconomic areas may have less investment in infrastructure (unsafe roads, fewer crossings), fewer resources for maintenance, greater exposure to environmental hazards, less political power to demand change, and emergency services may have longer response times. Marginalised communities may face additional risks from discrimination. Truly equitable safety would mean similar levels of protection regardless of location or identity - safe housing, well-maintained public spaces, equal access to safety education, and responsive emergency services everywhere. Achieving this requires systemic changes: investment decisions that prioritise highest-need areas, community voice in safety planning, addressing root causes like poverty and discrimination, and measuring outcomes by equity not just averages. This is fundamentally about recognising safety as a right, not a privilege dependent on where you live or who you are.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies systemic factors creating safety inequities. Articulates a vision of equitable safety. Proposes meaningful systemic changes. Shows sophisticated understanding of intersection between social justice and safety.

reflectionQuestions: How might your own cognitive biases affect how you perceive risks in your life?
What safety issues in your community do you think need more attention?
How could young people have more voice in safety decisions that affect them?

contentSections.title: Research on Risk: Psychological and Sociological Perspectives
contentSections.content: Research from psychology and sociology provides complementary insights into risk. Psychological research focuses on individual cognition: how people perceive, evaluate, and respond to risks. Key findings include the role of heuristics and biases, the affect heuristic (emotional reactions guiding judgement), and the psychometric paradigm (mapping what makes risks feel 'dread' or 'unknown'). Sociological research emphasises social construction: how risks are defined, communicated, and managed through social processes. Ulrich Beck's 'risk society' theory suggests modern societies are increasingly organised around managing manufactured risks. Synthesising these perspectives shows that risk is both objectively measurable and socially constructed, requiring approaches that address both dimensions.

contentSections.title: Policy Approaches to Risk Management
contentSections.content: Governments take different approaches to managing risk. Regulatory approaches set rules and standards (speed limits, building codes, safety standards). Economic approaches use incentives (insurance, taxes, subsidies). Information approaches provide education and disclosure. Voluntary approaches rely on industry self-regulation. Each approach has strengths and limitations: regulation can be inflexible but provides certainty; information empowers choice but assumes people can act on information; economic approaches can be efficient but may create inequity. Evaluating policy requires considering effectiveness at reducing harm, efficiency, equity, political feasibility, and ethical acceptability. Different risks may warrant different approaches.

contentSections.title: Addressing Complex and Emerging Risks
contentSections.content: Some safety challenges are 'wicked problems' - complex, with multiple stakeholders, contested definitions, and no clear solutions. Climate change affecting safety, emerging technologies, and pandemics are examples. Traditional risk assessment struggles with these because: causes and effects are complex and interconnected; uncertainty is high; values differ about acceptable risk levels; and solutions have unintended consequences. Approaches for complex risks include: systems thinking that considers interconnections; adaptive management that adjusts as learning occurs; participatory processes involving diverse stakeholders; and resilience frameworks that focus on capacity to respond rather than prediction.

contentSections.title: Ethics in Risk Management
contentSections.content: Risk management involves ethical considerations. Key questions include: How should risks and benefits be distributed across society? Who gets to decide what risks are acceptable? What is owed to future generations regarding long-term risks? How should uncertainty be handled when outcomes are potentially serious? Ethical principles relevant to risk include: proportionality (responses matching risk level); equity (fair distribution of risks and benefits); autonomy (respecting informed choice); precaution (erring on the side of caution for serious risks); and transparency (open communication about risks and uncertainties). These principles can conflict, requiring ethical reasoning to navigate difficult trade-offs.

remember.question: What is meant by 'wicked problems' in risk management?

options.text: Problems caused by evil people
options.feedback: 'Wicked' in this context is a technical term, not a moral judgment.

options.text: Complex challenges with no clear solution, where stakeholders disagree about the nature of the problem
options.feedback: Correct! Wicked problems are characterised by complexity, contested definitions, and lack of clear solutions.

options.text: Very dangerous risks
options.feedback: Wicked problems refer to complexity, not danger level.

options.text: Problems that have already been solved
options.feedback: Wicked problems are characterised by their difficulty to solve, not by being solved.

understand.question: Why might psychological and sociological perspectives on risk both be necessary for understanding safety issues?

options.text: Because researchers need to justify their different disciplines
options.feedback: The value is in what they reveal about risk, not disciplinary justification.

options.text: Because risk involves both individual perception and cognition AND social construction and collective action
options.feedback: Correct! Risk operates at both individual and social levels, requiring both perspectives to understand fully.

options.text: Because one perspective is right and the other is wrong
options.feedback: Both perspectives offer valuable insights; they're complementary not competing.

options.text: Because academic complexity makes research more impressive
options.feedback: The value is in improved understanding, not academic impressiveness.

apply.question: Apply systems thinking to a school safety issue such as bullying. How does this approach differ from a traditional focus on individual bullies and victims?

options.text: Systems thinking ignores individual behaviour completely
options.feedback: Systems thinking includes individual behaviour but places it within broader context.

options.text: Systems thinking examines interconnected factors like school culture, peer dynamics, staff capacity, policies, and community context rather than just individual actors
options.feedback: Correct! Systems thinking considers how multiple factors interact to create conditions where bullying occurs or is prevented.

options.text: Systems thinking focuses only on creating more rules
options.feedback: Rules are one element; systems thinking considers multiple interacting factors.

options.text: Systems thinking is too complicated for school issues
options.feedback: Systems thinking can be applied at any scale to understand interconnections.

analyse.question: Analyse the ethical tensions in applying the precautionary principle to emerging technology risks. What principles might conflict, and how might these tensions be navigated?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse ethical tensions. Key tensions: precaution vs innovation (limiting potential benefits); proportionality vs precaution (whether restrictions match uncertain risks); autonomy vs protection (individual choice vs collective safety); equity (who bears costs of precaution vs who bears risks of inaction). Navigation approaches: graduated responses, adaptive management, inclusive deliberation, transparency about uncertainty. Strong responses show sophisticated ethical reasoning about trade-offs.
successCriteria: Identifies multiple ethical tensions or conflicts
Explains the nature of each tension with examples
Proposes approaches for navigating these tensions
Demonstrates sophisticated ethical reasoning

evaluate.question: Evaluate the concept of 'acceptable risk'. Who should decide what level of risk is acceptable, and what criteria should guide this decision?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should critically evaluate this concept. Key considerations: acceptable to whom? Different stakeholders have different risk exposure and benefit. Criteria might include: consent and choice, fair distribution, severity of potential harm, reversibility, availability of alternatives, level of uncertainty. Governance questions: role of experts vs public, technocratic vs democratic decision-making, rights of affected communities. Strong responses question the concept while acknowledging practical need for thresholds.
successCriteria: Critically examines 'acceptable risk' as a concept
Considers who should be involved in such decisions
Identifies criteria for guiding acceptability decisions
Acknowledges complexity and differing perspectives

create.question: Design an innovative framework for addressing a complex safety challenge in your community or society (such as mental health safety, traffic safety, or environmental health). Your framework should address complexity, uncertainty, multiple stakeholders, and ethical considerations.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students design a comprehensive framework. Should include: clear articulation of the challenge and why it's complex; systems analysis of interconnected factors; process for inclusive stakeholder engagement; mechanisms for adaptive management under uncertainty; explicit ethical principles guiding decisions; indicators for monitoring outcomes; approach to equity considerations. Framework should demonstrate sophisticated understanding of complexity while remaining practically actionable.
successCriteria: Articulates the complex challenge clearly
Uses systems thinking to analyse interconnections
Includes meaningful stakeholder participation
Addresses uncertainty through adaptive approaches
Incorporates explicit ethical considerations

unistructural.stem: What is adaptive management in risk governance?
unistructural.modelResponse: Adaptive management treats policies as experiments and adjusts them based on outcomes.
unistructural.rubric: Correctly defines adaptive management as an approach that learns and adjusts based on outcomes.

multistructural.stem: List four different policy approaches governments can use to manage risk.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four policy approaches to managing risk are: 1) Regulatory approaches - setting rules and standards, 2) Economic approaches - using incentives like taxes or insurance, 3) Information approaches - education and disclosure, 4) Voluntary approaches - industry self-regulation.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant policy approaches such as regulatory, economic, informational, or voluntary approaches.

relational.stem: Explain how the concept of 'risk society' connects to understanding modern safety challenges.
relational.modelResponse: The 'risk society' concept, from sociologist Ulrich Beck, suggests that modern societies are increasingly organised around identifying, managing, and distributing manufactured risks. Unlike traditional hazards (natural disasters), manufactured risks come from modernisation itself - technology, industry, environmental change. This connects to modern safety challenges because many current risks (climate change, technological accidents, chemicals) are products of human activity and require collective management. The concept also highlights how risks are distributed unequally, how experts are both necessary and distrusted, and how risk perception becomes politically contested. Understanding safety challenges today requires recognising these systemic features of risk society - it's not just about individual hazards but about how societies generate and manage risks collectively.
relational.rubric: Explains the core concept of risk society. Connects it to specific modern safety challenges. Shows understanding of systemic nature of contemporary risk. Demonstrates synthesis of theoretical and practical considerations.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how artificial intelligence might change risk management in the future - both creating new risks and offering new tools. What ethical and governance frameworks would be needed?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: AI presents a dual-edged transformation for risk management. New risks include: algorithmic bias in safety-critical decisions, autonomous systems making high-stakes choices, cybersecurity vulnerabilities, job displacement affecting economic safety, and AI systems making errors at scale. New opportunities include: pattern detection for early warning, personalised safety interventions, real-time risk monitoring, and simulation for testing interventions. Ethical frameworks needed include: transparency requirements so affected parties understand AI decisions, accountability mechanisms when AI systems cause harm, equity considerations to prevent bias amplification, human oversight for critical decisions, and precautionary approaches for high-stakes applications. Governance frameworks might include: regulatory sandboxes for testing, international cooperation for global risks, multi-stakeholder bodies for standard-setting, and adaptive regulation that can keep pace with technology. Key challenges include the expertise gap between technologists and regulators, corporate interests in minimising oversight, and the difficulty of foreseeing emergent risks from complex systems.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies both risks and opportunities from AI in risk management. Proposes ethical frameworks with clear principles. Suggests governance approaches appropriate to the challenge. Demonstrates sophisticated understanding of technology governance challenges. Acknowledges uncertainty and need for adaptability.
